name: Baltimore Light RailLink
overview: The Light RailLink is a light rail system operated by the Maryland Transit Administration serving the Baltimore metropolitan area. Running 30 miles from Hunt Valley in northern Baltimore County through downtown Baltimore to Cromwell Station/Glen Burnie and BWI Airport in Anne Arundel County, it is one of the oldest modern light rail systems in the eastern United States. The system uses former railroad rights-of-way for much of its route and runs as a street-running railway through downtown on Howard Street.

history.title: Limited Service Opens
history.description: Light RailLink opens with limited service from Timonium Fairgrounds to Camden Yards for Baltimore Orioles games at the new Oriole Park at Camden Yards.

history.title: Full Daily Service Begins
history.description: Full daily service begins on the initial 9.4-mile segment from Timonium Fairgrounds to Camden Yards, comprising 14 stations.

history.title: Southern Extension Completed
history.description: Final southern stations open to Cromwell Station/Glen Burnie, completing the original 22.5-mile main line from Timonium to Glen Burnie.

history.title: Hunt Valley Extension
history.description: Line extended 4.5 miles north from Timonium to Hunt Valley, adding five new stations including park-and-ride facilities.

history.title: BWI Airport Branch and Penn Station Spur Open
history.description: Two short branches added: a 2.7-mile spur to BWI Thurgood Marshall Airport terminal and a 0.3-mile spur connecting to Penn Station for Amtrak and MARC transfers.

history.title: Hamburg Street Station Opens
history.description: Infill station opens adjacent to the new Ravens stadium (now M&T Bank Stadium), initially serving game days only. Later renamed Stadium/Federal Hill.

history.title: Double-Tracking Project Begins
history.description: Major $205 million reconstruction project to double-track most of the system begins. Southern section closed through much of 2004; northern section closed Januaryâ€“October 2005.

history.title: Double-Tracking Completed
history.description: Full service restored after completion of the double-tracking project, significantly improving frequency and reliability across the system.

history.title: Fleet Replacement Grant Awarded
history.description: MTA awarded $213.7 million federal grant to replace the entire 53-vehicle Light Rail fleet with new modern railcars as part of the Light Rail Modernization Program.
